trans-unit.source: Move data to and from File System | Azure Data Factory
trans-unit.target: Move data to and from File System | Azure Data Factory

trans-unit.source: Learn how to move data to/from on-premises File System using Azure Data Factory.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to move data to/from on-premises File System using Azure Data Factory.

trans-unit.source: This article outlines how you can use data factory copy activity to move data to and from on-premises file system.
trans-unit.target: This article outlines how you can use data factory copy activity to move data to and from on-premises file system.

trans-unit.source: This article builds on the <linkText>data movement activities</linkText><title></title> article which presents a general overview of data movement with copy activity and supported data store combinations.
trans-unit.target: This article builds on the <linkText>data movement activities</linkText><title></title> article which presents a general overview of data movement with copy activity and supported data store combinations.

trans-unit.source: Data factory supports connecting to and from on-premises File System via the Data Management Gateway.
trans-unit.target: Data factory supports connecting to and from on-premises File System via the Data Management Gateway.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>moving data between on-premises locations and cloud</linkText><title></title> article to learn about Data Management Gateway and step by step instructions on setting up the gateway.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>moving data between on-premises locations and cloud</linkText><title></title> article to learn about Data Management Gateway and step by step instructions on setting up the gateway.

trans-unit.source: Note: Apart from the Data Management Gateway no other binaries need to be installed to communicate to and from on-premises File System.
trans-unit.target: Note: Apart from the Data Management Gateway no other binaries need to be installed to communicate to and from on-premises File System.

trans-unit.source: Perform the following two steps to use a Linux file share with the File Server Linked Service:
trans-unit.target: Perform the following two steps to use a Linux file share with the File Server Linked Service:

trans-unit.source: Install <linkText>Samba</linkText><title></title> on your Linux Server.
trans-unit.target: Install <linkText>Samba</linkText><title></title> on your Linux Server.

trans-unit.source: Install and configure Data Management Gateway on a Windows server.
trans-unit.target: Install and configure Data Management Gateway on a Windows server.

trans-unit.source: Installing gateway on a Linux server is not supported.
trans-unit.target: Installing gateway on a Linux server is not supported.

trans-unit.source: The sample below shows:
trans-unit.target: The sample below shows:

trans-unit.source: A linked service of type <linkText>OnPremisesFileServer</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: A linked service of type <linkText>OnPremisesFileServer</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: A linked service of type <linkText>AzureStorage</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: A linked service of type <linkText>AzureStorage</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: An input <linkText>dataset</linkText><title></title> of type <linkText>FileShare</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: An input <linkText>dataset</linkText><title></title> of type <linkText>FileShare</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: An output <linkText>dataset</linkText><title></title> of type <linkText>AzureBlob</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: An output <linkText>dataset</linkText><title></title> of type <linkText>AzureBlob</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The <linkText>pipeline</linkText><title></title> with Copy Activity that uses <linkText>FileSystemSource</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>BlobSink</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The <linkText>pipeline</linkText><title></title> with Copy Activity that uses <linkText>FileSystemSource</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>BlobSink</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The sample below copies data belonging to a time series from on-premises file system to Azure blob every hour.
trans-unit.target: The sample below copies data belonging to a time series from on-premises file system to Azure blob every hour.

trans-unit.source: The JSON properties used in these samples are described in sections following the samples.
trans-unit.target: The JSON properties used in these samples are described in sections following the samples.

trans-unit.source: As a first step, do setup the data management gateway as per the instructions in the <linkText>moving data between on-premises locations and cloud</linkText><title></title> article.
trans-unit.target: As a first step, do setup the data management gateway as per the instructions in the <linkText>moving data between on-premises locations and cloud</linkText><title></title> article.

trans-unit.source: On-premises File Server linked service:
trans-unit.target: On-premises File Server linked service:

trans-unit.source: Azure Blob storage linked service:
trans-unit.target: Azure Blob storage linked service:

trans-unit.source: On-premises File System input dataset:
trans-unit.target: On-premises File System input dataset:

trans-unit.source: Data is picked up from a new file every hour with the path & filename reflecting the specific datetime with hour granularity.
trans-unit.target: Data is picked up from a new file every hour with the path & filename reflecting the specific datetime with hour granularity.

trans-unit.source: Setting “external”: ”true” and specifying externalData policy informs the Azure Data Factory service that the table is external to the data factory and not produced by an activity in the data factory.
trans-unit.target: Setting “external”: ”true” and specifying externalData policy informs the Azure Data Factory service that the table is external to the data factory and not produced by an activity in the data factory.

trans-unit.source: Azure Blob output dataset:
trans-unit.target: Azure Blob output dataset:

trans-unit.source: Data is written to a new blob every hour (frequency: hour, interval: 1).
trans-unit.target: Data is written to a new blob every hour (frequency: hour, interval: 1).

trans-unit.source: The folder path for the blob is dynamically evaluated based on the start time of the slice that is being processed.
trans-unit.target: The folder path for the blob is dynamically evaluated based on the start time of the slice that is being processed.

trans-unit.source: The folder path uses year, month, day, and hours parts of the start time.
trans-unit.target: The folder path uses year, month, day, and hours parts of the start time.

trans-unit.source: Copy activity:
trans-unit.target: Copy activity:

trans-unit.source: The pipeline contains a Copy Activity that is configured to use the above input and output datasets and is scheduled to run every hour.
trans-unit.target: The pipeline contains a Copy Activity that is configured to use the above input and output datasets and is scheduled to run every hour.

trans-unit.source: In the pipeline JSON definition, the source type is set to FileSystemSource and sink type is set to BlobSink.
trans-unit.target: In the pipeline JSON definition, the source type is set to FileSystemSource and sink type is set to BlobSink.

trans-unit.source: The sample below shows:
trans-unit.target: The sample below shows:

trans-unit.source: A linked service of type AzureSqlDatabase.
trans-unit.target: A linked service of type AzureSqlDatabase.

trans-unit.source: A linked service of type OnPremisesFileServer.
trans-unit.target: A linked service of type OnPremisesFileServer.

trans-unit.source: An input dataset of type AzureSqlTable.
trans-unit.target: An input dataset of type AzureSqlTable.

trans-unit.source: An output dataset of type FileShare.
trans-unit.target: An output dataset of type FileShare.

trans-unit.source: A pipeline with Copy activity that uses SqlSource and FileSystemSink.
trans-unit.target: A pipeline with Copy activity that uses SqlSource and FileSystemSink.

trans-unit.source: The sample copies data belonging to a time series from a table in Azure SQL database to a On-premises File System every hour.
trans-unit.target: The sample copies data belonging to a time series from a table in Azure SQL database to a On-premises File System every hour.

trans-unit.source: The JSON properties used in these samples are described in sections following the samples.
trans-unit.target: The JSON properties used in these samples are described in sections following the samples.

trans-unit.source: Azure SQL linked service:
trans-unit.target: Azure SQL linked service:

trans-unit.source: On-premises File Server linked service:
trans-unit.target: On-premises File Server linked service:

trans-unit.source: Azure SQL input dataset:
trans-unit.target: Azure SQL input dataset:

trans-unit.source: The sample assumes you have created a table “MyTable” in Azure SQL and it contains a column called “timestampcolumn” for time series data.
trans-unit.target: The sample assumes you have created a table “MyTable” in Azure SQL and it contains a column called “timestampcolumn” for time series data.

trans-unit.source: Setting “external”: ”true” and specifying externalData policy informs the Data Factory service that the table is external to the data factory and is not produced by an activity in the data factory.
trans-unit.target: Setting “external”: ”true” and specifying externalData policy informs the Data Factory service that the table is external to the data factory and is not produced by an activity in the data factory.

trans-unit.source: On-premises File System output dataset:
trans-unit.target: On-premises File System output dataset:

trans-unit.source: Data is copied to a new file every hour with the path for the blob reflecting the specific datetime with hour granularity.
trans-unit.target: Data is copied to a new file every hour with the path for the blob reflecting the specific datetime with hour granularity.

trans-unit.source: Pipeline with a Copy activity: The pipeline contains a Copy Activity that is configured to use the above input and output datasets and is scheduled to run every hour.
trans-unit.target: Pipeline with a Copy activity: The pipeline contains a Copy Activity that is configured to use the above input and output datasets and is scheduled to run every hour.

trans-unit.source: In the pipeline JSON definition, the source type is set to SqlSource and sink type is set to FileSystemSink.
trans-unit.target: In the pipeline JSON definition, the source type is set to SqlSource and sink type is set to FileSystemSink.

trans-unit.source: The SQL query specified for the SqlReaderQuery property selects the data in the past hour to copy.
trans-unit.target: The SQL query specified for the SqlReaderQuery property selects the data in the past hour to copy.

trans-unit.source: You can link an On-premises File System to an Azure Data Factory with On-Premises File Server Linked Service.
trans-unit.target: You can link an On-premises File System to an Azure Data Factory with On-Premises File Server Linked Service.

trans-unit.source: The following table provides description for JSON elements specific to On-Premises File Server Linked Service.
trans-unit.target: The following table provides description for JSON elements specific to On-Premises File Server Linked Service.

trans-unit.source: Property
trans-unit.target: Property

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Required
trans-unit.target: Required

trans-unit.source: type
trans-unit.target: type

trans-unit.source: The type property should be set to OnPremisesFileServer
trans-unit.target: The type property should be set to OnPremisesFileServer

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: host
trans-unit.target: host

trans-unit.source:
Host name of the server. Use ‘ \ ’ as the escape character as in the following example: if your share is: \\servername, specify \\\\servername.

If the file system is local to the gateway machine, use Local or localhost. If the file system is on a server different from the gateway machine, use \\\\servername.
trans-unit.target:
Host name of the server. Use ‘ \ ’ as the escape character as in the following example: if your share is: \\servername, specify \\\\servername.

If the file system is local to the gateway machine, use Local or localhost. If the file system is on a server different from the gateway machine, use \\\\servername.

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: userid
trans-unit.target: userid

trans-unit.source: Specify the ID of the user who has access to the server
trans-unit.target: Specify the ID of the user who has access to the server

trans-unit.source: No (if you choose encryptedCredential)
trans-unit.target: No (if you choose encryptedCredential)

trans-unit.source: password
trans-unit.target: password

trans-unit.source: Specify the password for the user (userid)
trans-unit.target: Specify the password for the user (userid)

trans-unit.source: No (if you choose encryptedCredential
trans-unit.target: No (if you choose encryptedCredential

trans-unit.source: encryptedCredential
trans-unit.target: encryptedCredential

trans-unit.source:
Specify the encrypted credentials that you can get by running the New-AzureDataFactoryEncryptValue cmdlet

Note: You must use the Azure PowerShell of version 0.8.14 or higher to use cmdlets such as New-AzureDataFactoryEncryptValue with type parameter set to OnPremisesFileSystemLinkedService
trans-unit.target:
Specify the encrypted credentials that you can get by running the New-AzureDataFactoryEncryptValue cmdlet

Note: You must use the Azure PowerShell of version 0.8.14 or higher to use cmdlets such as New-AzureDataFactoryEncryptValue with type parameter set to OnPremisesFileSystemLinkedService

trans-unit.source: No (if you choose to specify userid and password in plain text)
trans-unit.target: No (if you choose to specify userid and password in plain text)

trans-unit.source: gatewayName
trans-unit.target: gatewayName

trans-unit.source: Name of the gateway that the Data Factory service should use to connect to the on-premises file server
trans-unit.target: Name of the gateway that the Data Factory service should use to connect to the on-premises file server

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Setting Credentials and Security</linkText><title></title> for details about setting credentials for an on-premises File System data source.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Setting Credentials and Security</linkText><title></title> for details about setting credentials for an on-premises File System data source.

trans-unit.source: Example: Using username and password in plain text
trans-unit.target: Example: Using username and password in plain text

trans-unit.source: Example: Using encryptedcredential
trans-unit.target: Example: Using encryptedcredential

trans-unit.source: For a full list of sections & properties available for defining datasets, see the <linkText>Creating datasets</linkText><title></title> article. Sections like structure, availability, and policy of a dataset JSON are similar for all dataset types (Azure SQL, Azure Blob, Azure Table, On-premises File System, etc...).
trans-unit.target: For a full list of sections & properties available for defining datasets, see the <linkText>Creating datasets</linkText><title></title> article. Sections like structure, availability, and policy of a dataset JSON are similar for all dataset types (Azure SQL, Azure Blob, Azure Table, On-premises File System, etc...).

trans-unit.source: The typeProperties section is different for each type of dataset and provides information about the location, format etc. of the data in the data store.
trans-unit.target: The typeProperties section is different for each type of dataset and provides information about the location, format etc. of the data in the data store.

trans-unit.source: The typeProperties section for dataset of type FileShare dataset has the following properties.
trans-unit.target: The typeProperties section for dataset of type FileShare dataset has the following properties.

trans-unit.source: Property
trans-unit.target: Property

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Required
trans-unit.target: Required

trans-unit.source: folderPath
trans-unit.target: folderPath

trans-unit.source:
Path to the folder. Example: myfolder

Use escape character ‘ \ ’ for special characters in the string. For example: for folder\subfolder, specify folder\\subfolder and for d:\samplefolder, specify d:\\samplefolder.

You can combine this with partitionBy to have folder paths based on slice start/end date-times.
trans-unit.target:
Path to the folder. Example: myfolder

Use escape character ‘ \ ’ for special characters in the string. For example: for folder\subfolder, specify folder\\subfolder and for d:\samplefolder, specify d:\\samplefolder.

You can combine this with partitionBy to have folder paths based on slice start/end date-times.

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: fileName
trans-unit.target: fileName

trans-unit.source:
Specify the name of the file in the folderPath if you want the table to refer to a specific file in the folder. If you do not specify any value for this property, the table points to all files in the folder.

When fileName is not specified for an output dataset, the name of the generated file would be in the following this format:

Data..txt (for example: : Data.0a405f8a-93ff-4c6f-b3be-f69616f1df7a.txt
trans-unit.target:
Specify the name of the file in the folderPath if you want the table to refer to a specific file in the folder. If you do not specify any value for this property, the table points to all files in the folder.

When fileName is not specified for an output dataset, the name of the generated file would be in the following this format:

Data..txt (for example: : Data.0a405f8a-93ff-4c6f-b3be-f69616f1df7a.txt

trans-unit.source: No
trans-unit.target: No

trans-unit.source: partitionedBy
trans-unit.target: partitionedBy

trans-unit.source: partitionedBy can be leveraged to specify a dynamic folderPath, filename for time series data.
trans-unit.target: partitionedBy can be leveraged to specify a dynamic folderPath, filename for time series data.

trans-unit.source: For example folderPath parameterized for every hour of data.
trans-unit.target: For example folderPath parameterized for every hour of data.

trans-unit.source: No
trans-unit.target: No

trans-unit.source: Format
trans-unit.target: Format

trans-unit.source: Two formats types are supported: TextFormat, AvroFormat.
trans-unit.target: Two formats types are supported: TextFormat, AvroFormat.

trans-unit.source: You need to set the type property under format to either if this value.
trans-unit.target: You need to set the type property under format to either if this value.

trans-unit.source: When the forAvroFormatmat is TextFormat you can specify additional optional properties for format.
trans-unit.target: When the forAvroFormatmat is TextFormat you can specify additional optional properties for format.

trans-unit.source: See the format section below for more details.
trans-unit.target: See the format section below for more details.

trans-unit.source: No
trans-unit.target: No

trans-unit.source: fileFilter
trans-unit.target: fileFilter

trans-unit.source:
Specify a filter to be used to select a subset of files in the folderPath rather than all files.

Allowed values are: * (multiple characters) and ? (single character).

Examples 1: "fileFilter": "*.log"

Example 2: "fileFilter": 2014-1-?.txt"

Note: fileFilter is applicable for an input FileShare dataset
trans-unit.target:
Specify a filter to be used to select a subset of files in the folderPath rather than all files.

Allowed values are: * (multiple characters) and ? (single character).

Examples 1: "fileFilter": "*.log"

Example 2: "fileFilter": 2014-1-?.txt"

Note: fileFilter is applicable for an input FileShare dataset

trans-unit.source: No
trans-unit.target: No

trans-unit.source: compression
trans-unit.target: compression

trans-unit.source: Specify the type and level of compression for the data.
trans-unit.target: Specify the type and level of compression for the data.

trans-unit.source: Supported types are: GZip, Deflate, and BZip2 and supported levels are: Optimal and Fastest.
trans-unit.target: Supported types are: GZip, Deflate, and BZip2 and supported levels are: Optimal and Fastest.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Compression support</linkText><title></title> section for more details.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Compression support</linkText><title></title> section for more details.

trans-unit.source: No
trans-unit.target: No

trans-unit.source: filename and fileFilter cannot be used simultaneously.
trans-unit.target: filename and fileFilter cannot be used simultaneously.

trans-unit.source: As mentioned above, you can specify a dynamic folderPath, filename for time series data with partitionedBy.
trans-unit.target: As mentioned above, you can specify a dynamic folderPath, filename for time series data with partitionedBy.

trans-unit.source: You can do so with the Data Factory macros and the system variable SliceStart, SliceEnd that indicate the logical time period for a given data slice.
trans-unit.target: You can do so with the Data Factory macros and the system variable SliceStart, SliceEnd that indicate the logical time period for a given data slice.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Creating Datasets</linkText><title></title>, <linkText>Scheduling & Execution</linkText><title></title>, and <linkText>Creating Pipelines</linkText><title></title> articles to understand more details on time series datasets, scheduling and slices.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Creating Datasets</linkText><title></title>, <linkText>Scheduling & Execution</linkText><title></title>, and <linkText>Creating Pipelines</linkText><title></title> articles to understand more details on time series datasets, scheduling and slices.

trans-unit.source: In the above example {Slice} is replaced with the value of Data Factory system variable SliceStart in the format (YYYYMMDDHH) specified.
trans-unit.target: In the above example {Slice} is replaced with the value of Data Factory system variable SliceStart in the format (YYYYMMDDHH) specified.

trans-unit.source: The SliceStart refers to start time of the slice.
trans-unit.target: The SliceStart refers to start time of the slice.

trans-unit.source: The folderPath is different for each slice.
trans-unit.target: The folderPath is different for each slice.

trans-unit.source: For example: wikidatagateway/wikisampledataout/2014100103 or wikidatagateway/wikisampledataout/2014100104.
trans-unit.target: For example: wikidatagateway/wikisampledataout/2014100103 or wikidatagateway/wikisampledataout/2014100104.

trans-unit.source: In the above example, year, month, day, and time of SliceStart are extracted into separate variables that are used by folderPath and fileName properties.
trans-unit.target: In the above example, year, month, day, and time of SliceStart are extracted into separate variables that are used by folderPath and fileName properties.

trans-unit.source: If the format is set to TextFormat, you can specify the following optional properties in the Format section within the typeProperties section.
trans-unit.target: If the format is set to TextFormat, you can specify the following optional properties in the Format section within the typeProperties section.

trans-unit.source: Property
trans-unit.target: Property

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Required
trans-unit.target: Required

trans-unit.source: columnDelimiter
trans-unit.target: columnDelimiter

trans-unit.source: The character(s) used as a column separator in a file.
trans-unit.target: The character(s) used as a column separator in a file.

trans-unit.source: The default value is comma (,).
trans-unit.target: The default value is comma (,).

trans-unit.source: No
trans-unit.target: No

trans-unit.source: rowDelimiter
trans-unit.target: rowDelimiter

trans-unit.source: The character(s) used as a raw separator in file.
trans-unit.target: The character(s) used as a raw separator in file.

trans-unit.source: The default value is any of the following: [“\r\n”, “\r”,” \n”].
trans-unit.target: The default value is any of the following: [“\r\n”, “\r”,” \n”].

trans-unit.source: No
trans-unit.target: No

trans-unit.source: escapeChar
trans-unit.target: escapeChar

trans-unit.source: The special character used to escape column delimiter shown in content.
trans-unit.target: The special character used to escape column delimiter shown in content.

trans-unit.source: No default value.
trans-unit.target: No default value.

trans-unit.source:
You must specify no more than one character for this property.

For example, if you have comma (,) as the column delimiter but you want have comma character in the text (example: “Hello, world”), you can define ‘$’ as the escape character and use string “Hello$, world” in the source.

Note that you cannot specify both escapeChar and quoteChar for a table.
trans-unit.target:
You must specify no more than one character for this property.

For example, if you have comma (,) as the column delimiter but you want have comma character in the text (example: “Hello, world”), you can define ‘$’ as the escape character and use string “Hello$, world” in the source.

Note that you cannot specify both escapeChar and quoteChar for a table.

trans-unit.source: No
trans-unit.target: No

trans-unit.source: quoteChar
trans-unit.target: quoteChar

trans-unit.source:
The special character is used to quote the string value. The column and row delimiters inside of the quote characters would be treated as part of the string value. No default value. You must specify no more than one character for this property.

For example, if you have comma (,) as the column delimiter but you want have comma character in the text (example: ), you can define ‘"’ as the quote character and use string <"Hello, world"> in the source. This property is applicable to both input and output tables.

Note that you cannot specify both escapeChar and quoteChar for a table.
trans-unit.target:
The special character is used to quote the string value. The column and row delimiters inside of the quote characters would be treated as part of the string value. No default value. You must specify no more than one character for this property.

For example, if you have comma (,) as the column delimiter but you want have comma character in the text (example: ), you can define ‘"’ as the quote character and use string <"Hello, world"> in the source. This property is applicable to both input and output tables.

Note that you cannot specify both escapeChar and quoteChar for a table.

trans-unit.source: No
trans-unit.target: No

trans-unit.source: nullValue
trans-unit.target: nullValue

trans-unit.source: The character(s) used to represent null value in blob file content.
trans-unit.target: The character(s) used to represent null value in blob file content.

trans-unit.source: The default value is “\N”.>
trans-unit.target: The default value is “\N”.>

trans-unit.source: No
trans-unit.target: No

trans-unit.source: encodingName
trans-unit.target: encodingName

trans-unit.source:
Specify the encoding name. For the list of valid encoding names, see: Encoding.EncodingName Property.

For example: windows-1250 or shift_jis. The default value is: UTF-8.
trans-unit.target:
Specify the encoding name. For the list of valid encoding names, see: Encoding.EncodingName Property.

For example: windows-1250 or shift_jis. The default value is: UTF-8.

trans-unit.source: No
trans-unit.target: No

trans-unit.source: The following sample shows some of the format properties for TextFormat.
trans-unit.target: The following sample shows some of the format properties for TextFormat.

trans-unit.source: To use an escapeChar instead of quoteChar, replace the line with quoteChar with the following:
trans-unit.target: To use an escapeChar instead of quoteChar, replace the line with quoteChar with the following:

trans-unit.source: If the format is set to AvroFormat, you do not need to specify any properties in the Format section within the typeProperties section.
trans-unit.target: If the format is set to AvroFormat, you do not need to specify any properties in the Format section within the typeProperties section.

trans-unit.source: Example:
trans-unit.target: Example:

trans-unit.source: To use Avro format in a subsequent Hive table, refer to <linkText>Apache Hive’s tutorial</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To use Avro format in a subsequent Hive table, refer to <linkText>Apache Hive’s tutorial</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: FileSystemSource and FileSystemSink do not support any properties at this time.
trans-unit.target: FileSystemSource and FileSystemSink do not support any properties at this time.
